awd_titl_txt: An investigation of the evolutionary history of tuberculosis using ancient DNA
awd_abstract_narration: Tuberculosis (TB) is a re-emerging infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis and its close relatives, and it has a long history of affecting humans as shown by both historical data and lesions in skeletal remains. Recent molecular evidence indicates that M. tuberculosis is much older than previously thought, extending over three million years in the Old World and originating in Africa. The goal of this project is to analyze ancient DNA from skeletal samples dating before, during, and after the "Age of Exploration" that show evidence of tubercular bone lesions and integrate these data with data from modern strains of tuberculosis to assess the evolutionary history of tuberculosis and its effects on human history. The researchers will extract DNA from approximately 275 bone samples, test them for the presence of human and tuberculosis DNA, and then sequence the TB DNA. The data generated will be used to examine the relationship between TB strains in the Americas before and after European contact since it is hypothesized that European strains replaced those found in the Americas prior to contact. In addition, the investigators will assess the relationship between Asian (ancient and modern) TB strains and the strains present in the Americas prior to European contact, as well as assess whether the increase in prevalence of tuberculosis during the 17th and 18th centuries in Europe was due to the spread of new strains. Preliminary data indicate that about 17% of the samples contain TB DNA, and that the strains present in the Americas before European contact were different from the strains present today. This research will aid in the understanding of how human migration events and possible changes in the pathogenicity of M. tuberculosis over time have facilitated the spread of tuberculosis.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this proposal was to expand our knowledge about the evolutionary history of tuberculosis (TB) before and after the Age of Exploration with a particular focus on the question of how pre-contact American strains related to those found in the rest of the world. Over the course of this project, we extracted ancient DNA from almost 200 skeletons that show pathological lesions consistent with skeletal TB. The samples were from different time periods and locations throughout the Old and New World, but with a focus on the latter. The ancient DNA was tested for M. tuberculosis complex (MTBC) bacteria (which include strains affecting humans and other animals that cause clinical tuberculosis) using several quantitative PCR assays developed in our laboratory. Of these, 12 tested positive for MTBC DNA using stringent assignments. These samples as well as approximately 70 additional samples were also screened using targeted enrichment and sequencing of five TB genes in order to assess whether the DNA quantity was sufficient for genome sequencing. After these analyses, we sequenced the complete TB genome from three samples from three prehistoric Peruvian archaeological sites. Surprisingly, we found that pre-Columbian tuberculosis strains in Peru were most closely related to strains (falling in the M. pinnipedii group) that are adapted to seals and sea lions from the southern hemisphere rather than to strains found in Asia, which is what we had previously hypothesized. These results also lend support to the hypothesis that pre-Columbian strains were replaced by European strains post-contact. Our findings that M. pinnipedii was the agent responsible for at least some of the pre-contact tuberculosis present in the Americas demonstrate the importance of the human-wildlife exchange of pathogens. The spread of M. pinnipedii from Africa throughout the distribution of Southern Hemisphere seals and sea lions may also have conservation implications for those species.

In addition, our work suggests a most recent common ancestor for the M. tuberculosis complex bacteria less than 6000 years ago, which supports a dispersal of these pathogens during the Holocene.  This Holocene dispersal was not expected since previous research had suggested a much older origin of tuberculosis.  Thus, our results lead to a host of new questions about where and when the initial “jump” of the pathogen into humans occurred and whether there were other “jumps” that were ultimately unsuccessful (i.e. that either burned out or were replaced by more virulent strains, much as occurred after contact in the Americas). These results also focus attention on the role of zoonotic “jumps” by pathogens in ancient disease.

Over the course of this project, we presented our results at several scientific conferences including those sponsored by the Royal Society, the American Association of Physical Anthropologists, the International Society for Evolution, Medicine, and Public Health, and the Society for Molecular Biology and Evolution. A total of six graduate students and two undergraduate students worked on aspects of this project and received training in the Laboratory of Molecular Anthropology at ASU. In addition, our findings have been incorporated into a learning module for the junior level course “Disease and Human Evolution”, taken by approximately three hundred students each year.  Finally, graduate student, Kelly Harkins created an ‘Ask a biologist’ segment on “Indiana Jane” to talk about ancient DNA, bioarchaeology, and bacterial evolution (see http://askabiologist.asu.edu/explore/indiana-jane).
